Sediment_Collection_Depth_cm: 1-3 cm as described in the protocol
MiniDot_Notes: river stage/flow is visibly higher than initial visit. Visible white bubbles on surface flow. Weather is similar to the initial visit (80s and sunny, light wind).
Additional_Sampling_Notes: Sediment substrate surface very rich in dark green algae, with sandy textured material below algal/organic rich layer. Reach where sampling took place is effectively a partially natural flood conveyance channel: shallow sediment overlying concrete, pervasive rubbly material (cobble to boulder sized) placed across stream (see photos). Stream banks are natural sediment (as in CM_008-exposed photo) but inset within a large levee made of rip-rap and concrete. Upstream of site (~800m at Hellman Rd crossing), the stream is a flood conveyance channel lined 100% with concrete. Additionally, looks like some flow is siphoned off immediately upstream of sampling site (just below Hellman Rd crossing) to Mill Creek Wetlands as a form of stormwater/irrigation runoff treatment.
Hydrograph_Online: https://waterdata.usgs.gov/nwis/uv?site_no=11073495  [USGS gauge located a few kilometers upstream of site, but likely representative]

Sediment_Collection_Depth_cm: 1-3 cm as described in the protocol
MiniDot_Notes: a boat passed around 12:25, may have impacted O2 level.  minor wake.
Additional_Sampling_Notes: water was very murky and therefore was difficult to image directly downwards. even though depositional environment was indicated as shallow water on the metadata form, it was also on the insider bend of the river. sediment was generally very fine grained and organic rich- it was difficult, however, to push through the sieve.  therefore we collected as much fine grained muds as possible (i.e. there still may be a few larger bits in there)

Sediment_Collection_Depth_cm: 1-3 cm as described in the protocol
MiniDot_Notes: Sensor held in place with a stick stuck in the  sediment.  Sensor positioned closer to the main channel than the sediment sampling, which was about a half meter closer to the bank.
Additional_Sampling_Notes: The second sediment RNAlater tube leaked during shipping and only contained 15 ml of RNAlater.  We added 0.2micron filter sterilized homemade RNAlater up to a total of 30ml prior to sampling. Sediments included a lot of organic materials that were served out including sticks, leaves, and some evergreen needles. Sampling site was in Avery Park in Corvallis, OR. River flow was very slow. Sampling site was at the downriver end of a gravel bar positioned on an inside bend in the river. There were overhanging deciduous trees.
Hydrograph_Online: https://waterdata.usgs.gov/monitoring-location/14171000/ this site is some distance upriver from the sampling site.

Sediment_Collection_Depth_cm: 3-10cm in some places
Additional_Sampling_Notes: River was pretty flat with steep incised banks near access point except a few feet away from a boat ramp structure, which is where I sampled. I was in ankle deep mud. I thought  placed the sensor upstream, but it was apparently downstream. However, the bayou was practically a swamp and hardly flowing. Also, there was animal carcass upstream! (some large rodent like nutria)

Site_Name: NSF Long Term Ecological Research (LTER) site: Baltimore Ecosystem Study
Additional_Sampling_Notes: Conductivity: 1430 millisiemens. Conductivity and temperature tested with ECTestr11 Dual Range. Amber tube with yellow tape was mistakenly briefly unscrewed before sampling.

The field notes contain the following errors. which are corrected in this form:
- the written notes list the U-M distance as 5m (should be 10m). and D-M distance as 10m (should be 5m).
- access to sunlight: D and M have no shade (0% shading and 100% sunlight. instead of 100% canopy cover). The upstream site (U) has about 50% shading. 
Pictures: given the turbidity of the water. no pictures of the sediment could be taken. Sediments were collected by diving down into the water and scooping up sediment. The pictures uploaded represent the setting on land. not in the river. Sediment samples at D and M were fairly muddy. several sediment scoops at the upstream site contained a fair amount of leaves that were removed. 
Filter: the filter clogged after running the second set of replicates and at that point. we switched to the second filter (keeping the first filter clean). Filtering became difficult quickly again and filling vial ICR3 was challenging. When collecting samples for the third replicate for cations (CAT3). the sample collapsed (air might have gotten into the filter?) and water passed through the filter much more easily. We continued sampling CAT3. but the sample is much darker in color. indicating that the filter didn't work. and I suggest to discard that sample. We continued to filter the 125mL vial at the very end (S19S_0011_MER). After a little while. the filtering became harder again. so we discarded the water in it. filtered some more (~10mL). rinsed the bottle with that water and discarded it. and then filtered the required ~125mL. Thus. that sample *may* be valid. Given the above issues with filter #2. we preserved the first filter for microbial analyses with RNALater.

Site_Name: US DOE Biological and Environmental Research (BER) Scientific Focus Area (SFA) watershed testbed site
Additional_Sampling_Notes:
Weather was clear and sunny at the time of sampling.  The creek was very turbid due to rains the previous day.  

For the third 4-mL zero head space sample. the bottom of the glass vial cracked and fell off when screwing the lid onto the vial.  The sample was lost.

We were able to use one filter for most of the filtered water samples and had to change filters after filtering ~30 mL sample into the 125 mL PETG bottle.  It was not possible to filter an additional 700 mL through that filter.

NSF Long Term Ecological Research (LTER) site: Kellogg Biological Station
Additional_Sampling_Notes: Site is over 4km north/upstream of USGS gauging station with only one tributary (Ransom Creek) in between.  Discharge correction factor of 0.89 used to remove mean tributary discharge contribution.  i.e. USGS discharge of Augusta Creek on 12 Aug 2019 = 33 ft3/s = 0.93 m3/s.  Corrected for Ransom Creek. discharge at C Avenue site = 0.83 m3/s

River_Gradient: Relatively steep gradient (e.g., mountainous or hilly terrain)
Additional_Sampling_Notes: In addition to grass & broadleaf deciduous trees. there are many large shrubs/bushes on edges of stream channel. Upstream and Midstream samples were taken upstream of the gauging station (weir). downstream site is located downstream of the weir. Cows have access to the stream. The height of the water column is reported as the height where sediment is collected. Depth of the river at the deepest point in the cross-section at these locations is ~25cm.

General_Vegetation: Needleleaf evergreen tree, Broadleaf deciduous tree
River_Gradient: Relatively steep gradient (e.g., mountainous or hilly terrain)
Sediment_Collection_Depth_cm: 1-3 cm as described in the protocol
Additional_Sampling_Notes: Cotton strips bricks were found angled up out of the water with the tea infusers facing sky. Both the brick and sensors were found in fairly shallow water near the bank. Based on the HOBO pressure date, there were three large flashy events (quick, substantial increase in pressure follow by an almost as quick and large decrease in pressure), that likely flushed and moved the bricks/sensors from their original location.

Sediment_Collection_Depth_cm: 3-10cm in some places
MiniDot_Notes: The water was likely just hovering above 0C. There were small chunks of ice floating in water. We placed the sensor on a rock anchored by another rock, but when we went to retrieve it, it had dislodge from its original spot and was resting on the river bed.
Additional_Sampling_Notes: WIN-1 - one drop of water dripped off glove and potentially into the sample bottle.

Additional_Sampling_Notes: Had trouble with getting the sediment passed from the sieve into the sample bottle so we ended up not using the sieve. Most of the sediment was also larger than 2mm in size so we were not getting much to pass through. We also did not get a photo of the exposed shoreline sediments. We forgot a ruler but used a fireball bottle for scale. Fireball bottle was later measured to be 13cm in height.

Sediment_Collection_Depth_cm: 1-3 cm as described in the protocol
MiniDot_Notes: We finished sampling in about 45 minutes at the site, and it was about 8:30pm. We waited for 15 minutes to collect the sensor. The sensor was in water for 61 minutes from 7:44pm to 8:45pm. We had to leave because it is already dark, and we needed to drive about one hour to be back to my lab.
Additional_Sampling_Notes: We arrived at the site at about 2pm on 5/22/2023, and a heavy rain started at about 2:10pm. We had to leave the site for another site. We came back around 7:30pm, and it was overcast.

Sediment_Collection_Depth_cm: 1-3 cm as described in the protocol
MiniDot_Notes: Sensor was 1 m from "depositional bank" ( = sand, gravel over bedrock that has a stagnant, shallow water pool between it and the "real" bank of the river.). The sensor was about 5 m from the "real" bank at that point in time. We took water samples within 10 m down the river from the sensor because the river sediment was so fine that sampling disturbed sediment so that it may have interfered with the sensor readings.
Additional_Sampling_Notes: - Samples packed in ice 5:00 - 5:15  pm on 1/17/23 and driven to FedEx with a 5:45 pm pick up for overnight packages. Expected delivery at PNNL before 4 pm on 1/18/23. Tracking info: https://www.fedex.com/fedextrack/?trknbr=817383356941&trkqual=2459962000~817383356941~FX. Site weather = Sunny, 22C. I provided a diagram (sketch) of the site with estimated distances in the uploaded files section in this form.The bank was level with fine and course sediments - if vegetation was present it was grasses on the bank (grasses appeared to be some Phragmites sp. and/or Paspalum denticulatum). There was a steep incline up to a terrace (but it was not more than 4 m long) and the terrace was vegetated with hardwoods (dominated by Platanus occidentalis). Most importantly, there was a dry, ephemeral tributary at the "real" bank (see sensor notes above)nearest to area we sampled. There was evidence of erosional deposition present. The source of the ravine/tributary was a bare/muddy watering area of a densely populated cattle ranch. The river sediment was so fine that getting it through the filters was incredibly difficult (especially when using a 50 ml syringe) and therefore we used many filters. It would have been easier to use smaller syringes, but trying to fill a 500 ml bottle with a small syringe would have been tedious). Therefore the "filtered water" sample (BWT - filtered) had to be filled with non-filtered water. We managed to fill it to nearly 150 ml of filtered water, but it took 30 mins and we couldn't do that 3-4 more times. Therefore, we filled the remaining 400 ml with unfiltered water. Unfiltered noted on bottle. The unfiltered bottle (BWT) is only 50% filled due to the cap not being screwed on enough during transport to lab. All vials/bottles were individually wrapped and so the water did not contaminate other samples in the cooler. Apologies - we had a team of 5 doing the sampling (and it took 2 hours). Collection photo - difficult to get 1 m2 since the whole team is super short.

Sediment_Collection_Depth_cm: 1-3 cm as described in the protocol
MiniDot_Notes: Deployed upstream of collection point in fast flowing portion of channel.  Sensor window was clean on retrieval.
Additional_Sampling_Notes: Heavy rain in the area for several hours in the morning before sampling but creek water level had not yet responded at the time of sampling.  Water was clear with no obvious sign of elevated suspended solids.  This location coincides with a site for the ORNL WaDE SFA - a dissolved oxygen sensor (same miniDOT as used by WHONDRS) and pressure/conductivity/temperature logger were deployed in early March 2023, logging at 15-min interval.  The sensor data was downloaded the same day as sampling for WHONDRS. These sensors will be retrieved from the site sometime in late fall 2023.

Additional_Sampling_Notes: I contaminated the labeled filter and #1 ICR bottle at the beginning of "sample phase 1". I located the spare sterivex filter with the luer-lok, extra needle and spare 60ml glass amber bottle and re-collected the #1 ICR sample. After performing all the water collections I preserved the filter that I used for water collection not the one with the label as that was contaminated and not used in the sampling. I did not transfer any of the labels from the original 60ml glass amber vial or the filter but have sent them back in the shipment- labeled as contaminated. The thermometers that I brought sampling were for taking human's temperature and could not register the stream water temperature.

Additional_Sampling_Notes: Ice chunks in the river mixed/floating along with small woody debris and some foam.  Lots of trash on the banks, some zebra mussel shells. Additional_Sampling_Notes: Water was slightly turbid (65.3 NTU), our ProDSS measured 109.7 % sat and 9.10 mg/L DO at start of minidot deployment. Specific Conductivity was 412.2 uS/cm. The filtered water bottle had ~100mL of unfiltered water in it, we went through all the filters.  The sieving was taking too long, so we started to pick out the large bits by hand (mostly snail shells).  Not all the photos fit, here's a link for more: https://www.dropbox.com/sh/386901lt9ci5plt/AAD9jwSM-Lycc65zSz11YRLAa?dl=0. We have 47 years of data from this location- nutrients and TSS.  There's a sonde deployed as well, if you need any diel DO or other details.
